displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary: - Sentiment skews favorable or open-minded. Approximately 70–80% view influencers as a legitimate, even valuable profession enabled by social media, citing entertainment, useful recommendations, knowledge-sharing, and meaningful audience connections. Many note the flexibility and income potential, and some see influencers as a modern counterpart to traditional celebrities or media. - About 30–40% express caveats around authenticity, responsibility, and homogenized trends—concerns that influencer culture can encourage conformity, oversharing, or undue influence, and that staying genuine and accountable matters. - A small minority (around 10–20%) hold a clearly negative view, describing influencers as inauthentic or annoying and criticizing the public’s susceptibility. - Additional themes include: influencers as emerging “new media” that can surface information outside mainstream outlets; recognition that the role shapes trends and public opinion; and calls for ethical standards, transparency, and creativity to preserve trust and originality.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments: - Sentiment: Skews positive; approximately 70–80% express favorable or supportive views, around 10% are negative, and the rest are mixed or neutral. - Legitimacy and role: Many view influencing as a real profession that shapes trends and connects with audiences, offering entertainment, advice, product recommendations, and even alternative news. Some compare influencers to traditional celebrities but note they can feel more accessible and personal. - Opportunities: Highlighted benefits include flexibility, the convenience of online work, significant income potential, and career-opening doors. - Concerns and caveats: Key worries involve authenticity and responsibility, perceptions of inauthentic or manipulative behavior, audience susceptibility, and trend-chasing that leads to homogeneity and reduced creativity. - Expectations: A desire for influencers to remain authentic, responsible, and creative, balancing monetization and trend relevance with transparency and originality.

Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary: - Sentiment skews favorable or open-minded. Approximately 70–80% view influencers as a legitimate, even valuable profession enabled by social media, citing entertainment, useful recommendations, knowledge-sharing, and meaningful audience connections. Many note the flexibility and income potential, and some see influencers as a modern counterpart to traditional celebrities or media. - About 30–40% express caveats around authenticity, responsibility, and homogenized trends—concerns that influencer culture can encourage conformity, oversharing, or undue influence, and that staying genuine and accountable matters. - A small minority (around 10–20%) hold a clearly negative view, describing influencers as inauthentic or annoying and criticizing the public’s susceptibility. - Additional themes include: influencers as emerging “new media” that can surface information outside mainstream outlets; recognition that the role shapes trends and public opinion; and calls for ethical standards, transparency, and creativity to preserve trust and originality.

[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

answer.text_box: I think that, even though some are not positive, that it is a valid profession.
